symptoms.name: Skin lesions
symptoms.severity: Variable, can range from small and localized to large nodules or plaques
symptoms.pattern: Develops on exposed skin within weeks or months of infection; can appear later, sometimes in context of trauma; progresses from papules or plaques to ulcers with raised border and central crater; can be painless or painful if superinfected

symptoms.name: Mucosal ulcers
symptoms.severity: Can be severe, leading to facial disfigurement; potentially fatal if untreated
symptoms.pattern: Develops in nose, mouth, or throat; often appears years after initial skin lesions heal; can cause bleeding, stuffiness, inflamed mucosa, brassy cough, or hoarseness; in advanced cases, can lead to ulcerative destruction of mouth, nose, larynx, and pharynx

physical_findings: Laryngeal or tracheal damage (in advanced cases)
risk_factors: Malnutrition (protein-energy deficiency, iron, vitamin A, zinc deficiency)

required: Detection of Leishmania parasites or DNA in infected tissue (microscopic examination, culture, PCR)
